options.text: supercooled water droplets form small snow crystals and reduce visibility.
tiny water droplets in the air remain as liquid in temperatures below freezing and reduce visibility.
tiny water droplets in the air change into clear ice as soon as the air temperature falls below 0°C
saturated air with water droplets is cooled down below 0°C and small ice crystals reduce visibility.

variant.question: What conditions are most likely to lead to the formation of hill fog?

options.text: Humid stable air mass, wind blowing towards the hills.
Precipitation which is lifted by the action of moderate winds striking the range.
Clear skies, steep slopes, calm or light winds, with relatively low humidity.
High relative humidity, wind blowing parallel to range and an unstable air mass.

variant.question: Which type of fog is likely to form when air having temperature of 15°C and dew point of 12°C blows at 10 knots over a sea surface having temperatures of 5°C?

options.text: Advection fog.
Radiation fog.
Frontal fog.
Steam fog.

variant.question: Which of these statements about steam fog are correct or incorrect?
firstCorrectStatements: Steam fog is formed in air with cold air mass properties
firstIncorrectStatements: Steam fog is not formed in air with cold air mass properties
secondCorrectStatements: Steam fog is not formed only in windless conditions
secondIncorrectStatements: Steam fog is formed only in windless conditions

variant.question: Which of the following statements is correct as regards fog, mist or haze?

options.text: Mist consists of fine dust or salt particles in the air that reduce visibility to a lesser extent than fog.
Fog is water that has condensed close to ground level, producing a cloud of very small droplets that reduces visibility to less than 1 km.
Haze is made up of fine ice crystals suspended in the atmosphere that reduce visibility to between 1 km and 5 km.
Haze is a dense suspension in the air of small particles produced by burning that reduces visibility to less than 1 km.

variant.question: Which of the following would most favour the formation of surface fog (all other elements being constant)?

options.text: Strong surface winds.
Strong anabatic winds.
Increased insolation, which will warm the air and cause condensation.
Increased radiation from the earth overnight, cooling the air above the surface.

variant.question: Fog or mist will start to form when the air becomes saturated, this may happen when: Temperature (1) \_\_\_\_\_ to the dew point temperature and/or there is (2) \_\_\_\_\_ in dew point temperature to that of the air temperature.

options.text: (1) increases; (2) an increase.
(1) reduces; (2) a reduction.
(1) reduces; (2) an increase.
(1) increases; (2) a reduction.

variant.question: Check the correctness of the following statements.
firstCorrectStatements: Fog only occurs in air with warm air mass properties.
firstIncorrectStatements: Fog only occurs in air with cold air mass properties.
secondCorrectStatements: Both mist and haze are not formed by water droplets and/or ice crystals in the atmosphere.
secondIncorrectStatements: Both mist and haze are formed by water droplets and/or ice crystals in the atmosphere.

variant.question: In which weather type would steaming fog be most likely?

options.text: Sea temperature of +15°C, Ground 0°C, Air temperature +5°C.
Sea temperature of +15°C, Ground -5°C, Air temperature -5°C.
Sea temperature of +5°C, Ground -5°C, Air temperature +5°C.
Sea temperature of +15°C, Ground -5°C, Air temperature 0°C.
The fog can form by any usual process but it becomes freezing fog when the temperature is below 0 °C.
By advection between the 60°N and higher latitudes.
By advection when the wind speed is between 5-10 kt and the OAT is between 0°C and 5°C.
By radiation in the early mornings.
ice crystals.
frozen water droplets.
supercooled water droplets.
frozen minute snow flakes.
